item.title: Greg Wilson
item.description: I will not be attending SciPy 2023 - I cannot in good conscience spend money in a state (Texas) that is trying to erase members of my family.

item.title: Daniel Lakens
item.description: Page where John Venn (1866) first describes the 'sharpshooter fallacy', or drawing the target *after* making the shot. Of course, the sharpshooter might still be a good shot - but nothing has been done to severely test they are not.

item.title: RaphaÃ«l LÃ©vy
item.description: "What is at stake? False claims and inappropriate exaggerations (hypes & alarmism) about scientific and technological possibilities may prompt malicious action (e.g., poor health decisions, misdirected investments and resources, understudying of other solutions and pathways of scientific endeavor and, more generally, jeopardize trust in science)."

item.title: Jon Worth
item.description: And really the sheer absurdity of European SleeperHere are two determined guys. They lease a freight locomotive, 2 ancient sleeping cars (at least with air con), 6 couchettes without air con (also old) and 2 seating carriagesAnd they manage to run a Berlin-Brussels night train, something that others - like DB, NS or SNCB - could *much more easily do with their financial means* BUT REFUSE TO EVEN TRYAnd basic though it is itâ€™s booked up all summer

item.title: A.J. Fish
item.description: For anyone grasping the hybrid [horror movie]/[comedy of manners] that is the **Hyped AI Rollout of 2023** I cannot recommend this video enough. It's even better on a second viewing. "A.I. and Stochastic Parrots | FACTUALLY with Emily Bender and Timnit Gebru" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jAHRbFetqII&t=3398s Adam Conover interviewing Dr. Timnit Gebru, Electrical Engineering Phd and Dr. Emily Bender, linguistics professor sorting the "safety" from the "ethics" and real from the sparks. #AI #AIHype #AISafety #AIEthics

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: That revolutionary new fMRI technique for detecting neuronal activity (DIANA)? Guess what happened next.https://pubpeer.com/publications/0EF432E4E7D84352E9B582CEC6DF07#1bioRxiv preprints "contradictory results" are really useful. And whoever is posting them to PubPeer is perfoming a real public service, because it is difficult for readers to discover them.

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: @BorisBarbour diggety that was fast!

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: @schoppik I guess it's not fabulously difficult to redo the experiment? And preprints are terrific for getting the result out, because nobody can gate-keep them.The faster the feedback of failed replications, the better. But no doubt a bunch of jobs, promotions and grants have still already been obtained. And they'll probably have a Science paper for life. For removing a few outliers.

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: @BorisBarbour 100% agree on the utility of preprints. Maybe there's a "can't replicate this" letter to Science working its way through their system of back and forth now but this is out there hopefully saving people time.
